document.docAuthor: Chan, Benny K. K., Corbari, Laure, Rodriguez Moreno, Paula A. & Jones, Diana S.
document.docTitle: Arcoscalpellum epeeum Chan, Corbari, Moreno & Jones, 2014, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Two new deep-sea stalked barnacles, Arcoscalpellum epeeum sp. nov. and Gymnoscalpellum indopacificum sp. nov., from the Coral Sea, with descriptions of the penis in Gymnoscalpellum dwarf males

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new deep-sea stalked barnacles, Arcoscalpellum epeeum sp. nov. and Gymnoscalpellum indopacificum sp. nov., from the Coral Sea, with descriptions of the penis in Gymnoscalpellum dwarf males

, depth: 458–512 m ).
Diagnosis. Fourteen fully calcified capitular plates, surfaces pubescent, carina sword-shaped, long, narrow, straight, apex sharp, 1 / 4 of total carinal length extending beyond apices of terga.

Description of holotype .
Female. Fourteen fully calcified, white plates, surfaces pubescent, covered by pale yellow, short setae (
Fig. 2
A–C). Tergum quadrangular, carinal margin longest, 1 / 3 of distal end of carinal margin bent away from carina, occludent margin straight, umbo apical, apex acute (
Fig. 2
A–C). Scutum quadrangular, occlusal margin slightly convex, tergal margin concave, lateral and basal margins straight, umbo apical (
Fig. 2
A). Upper latus triangular (
Fig. 2
A), tergal margin convex, scutal and lateral margins straight, umbo apical (
Fig. 2
A). Inframedian latus small, triangular, umbo apical. Rostrolatus quadrilateral, flattened, width 4 times height (
Fig. 2
A). Carinolatus quadragular, umbo recurved (
Fig. 2
A). Carina very long, narrow, sword-shaped, apex acute, carina extending beyond tergum about 1 / 4 its total length (
Fig. 2
A, C). Rostrum minute, almost covered by paired rostral-laterals (
Fig. 2
B, E).

Maxilla bilobed (
Fig. 3
A), serrulate setae distributed along cutting edge (
Fig. 3
B), dense setae apically. Maxillule cutting edge without notch (
Fig. 3
C), cutting edge wide, with 20 or more cuspidate setae (
Fig. 3
C). Mandible with 3 equally spaced teeth (
Fig. 3
D), inferior angle blunt, with about 12 cuspidate setae (
Fig. 3
D, E). Mandibular palp narrow (
Fig. 3
F), elongated, serrulate setae on superior margin and distally (
Fig. 3
G), inferior margin naked. Labrum bullate, cutting margin slightly concave, cutting edge smooth (
Fig. 3
H).

Cirrus I short, separated from cirri II–VI, rami subequal (
Fig. 4
A); anterior ramus shorter, flattened, 10 ovalshaped segments; posterior ramus longer, slender, 17 -segmented (
Fig. 4
A); both rami bearing serrulate setae (
Fig. 4
B). Cirri II–VI long, slender, similar in length. Cirrus II with anterior ramus 21 -segmented, posterior 28 - segmented (
Fig. 4
C); intermediate segments of both rami with 4 pairs of long, serrulate setae and 1 pair of short, serrulate setae (
Fig. 4
D). Cirrus III with anterior ramus 24 -segmented, inner ramus 24 -segmented (broken) (
Fig. 4
E); intermediate segments of both rami bearing 4 pairs of long, serrulate setae and 1 pair of short, serrulate setae (
Fig. 4
F). Cirrus IV with anterior ramus 25 -segmented, posterior ramus 23 -segmented (
Fig. 4
G), intermediate segments of both rami bearing 3 pairs of long serrulate setae and 1 pair of short serrulate setae (
Fig. 4
H). Cirrus V, anterior ramus 24 -segmented (broken at distal ends), posterior ramus 25 -segmented (broken at distal ends) (
Fig. 5
A). Cirrus VI, anterior ramus 23 -segmented, posterior ramus 24 -segmented (distal ends of both rami broken) (
Fig. 5
C), intermediate segments of both rami of cirri V and VI bearing 4 pairs of long serrulate setae and 1 pair of short, serrulate setae (
Fig. 5
B, D). Caudal appendage short, 1 -segmented, distal end blunt with bundle of serrulate setae, length less than height of basal segment of pedicle of cirrus VI (
Fig. 5
E, F).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2 .
Arcoscalpellum epeeum
sp. nov.
A–C: holotype (MNHN-IU-2013-7431); D–F: Paratype (MNHN-IU-2013-7432). A, Lateral and external view of capitulum showing arrangement of capitular plates. B, Rostral view of capitulum, C. Carinal view of capitulum. D, Dissected capitulum (somatic body removed) showing location of receptacles (circled) that house dwarf males. E, Minute rostrum observed from rostral view. F, Magnified view of receptacles showing dwarf males. c—carina, ul—upper latus, s—scutum, t—tergum, rl—rostral latus, cl—carinal latus, iml—infra-median latus, am—adductor muscle of scutum.

FIGURE 3 .
Arcoscalpellum epeeum
sp. nov.
Holotype (MNHN-IU-2013-7431) mouth parts. A, Maxilla. B, Serrulate setae on maxilla. C, Maxillule. D, Mandible. E, Inferior angle. F, Mandibulatory palp. G, Serrulate setae on tip of mandibular palp. H, Cutting edge of labrum. Scale bars in µm.

FIGURE 4 .
Arcoscalpellum epeeum
sp. nov.
Holotype (MNHN-IU-2013-7431). A, Cirrus I. B, Serrulate setae on posterior ramus of cirrus I. C, Cirrus II. D, Intermediate segment of anterior ramus of cirrus II. E, Cirrus III. F, Intermediate segment of anterior ramus of cirrus III. G, Cirrus IV. H, Intermediate segment of anterior ramus of cirrus II. Scale bars in µm.

FIGURE 5 .
Arcoscalpellum epeeum
sp. nov.
Holotype (MNHN-IU-2013-7431). A, Cirrus V. B, Serrulate setae on posterior ramus of cirrus V. C, Cirrus VI. D, Intermediate segment of anterior ramus of cirrus VI. E, Caudal appendages observed under stereomicroscope. F, Caudal appendage observed under light microscope, showing setae at tip. G, Dwarf males, showing antennules. H, Surface of dwarf males showing fan-shaped denticles. Scale bars in µm.

FIGURE 6 .
Arcoscalpellum epeeum
sp. nov.
Paratypes (MNHN-IU-2013-8584). Stn. DW1734. – Showing ontogenetic variation in shape and size of carina.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dwarf males absent from holotype ; present in paratypes , embedded in paired, oval-shaped receptacles located at inner edge of scutal plates, just above adductor muscles (
Fig. 2
D, F), 2 or 3 dwarf males in each receptacle (
Fig. 2
F). Dwarf males with shell plates absent, peanut shaped, anterior and posterior ends swollen, middle portion narrowed (
Fig. 5
G), denticles arranged in fan shape, located on surface (
Fig. 5
H); no penis observed extending from aperture.
Etymology. The species is named for the sword-shaped carina, resembling a French word “épée”.

Remarks. Of the
Arcoscalpellum
species described to date, no species have been reported with a long, sharp, sword-like carina that extends much beyond the apices of the terga. A long, sharp carina is present during the ontogeny of
Arcoscalpellum epeeum
sp. nov.
, being relatively straighter in younger specimens and then becoming curved inward in larger individuals (
Fig. 6
).

The genus
Arcoscalpellum
is one of the most diverse of the scalpellid genera. Currently, 44 species are recognised in the genus, with one species,
Arcoscalpellum spinum
Newman & Ross, 1998
, classified under the subgenus Vetecroscalpellum
Newman & Ross, 1998
.
Arcoscalpellum epeeum
sp. nov.
occurs in the Coral Sea, in the waters of New Caledonia and Vanuatu , but was not present in the extensive barnacle collections made by French expeditions off the Solomons, Tonga , Papua New Guinea and Fiji , or Madagascar in the Indian Ocean (about 1305 specimens corresponding to 300 localities throughout the Indo-Pacific).

Currently, there are no community level studies to examine barnacles from seamounts. The recent rich collections in the Tropical Deep-Sea Benthos programme will open up future research initiatives to carry out community based comparisons of deep-sea barnacles from seamounts and adjacent slope habitats.
